Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Risk Analysis for Extremes in the Earth System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Workshop on Risk Analysis for Extremes in the Earth System" will take place at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab in Berkeley, Califirnia, on July 22-24, 2019. This workshop will serve two complementary purposes. The first is to provide a venue for statisticians and Earth scientists to share ideas and facilitate collaboration aimed at understanding rare, high-impact events in the Earth system. The second is to introduce graduate students, as well as others wishing to enter into the area of extreme value analysis, to the techniques and challenges that are unique to studying rare events.

The first day of the workshop will feature a pair of short courses, one on contemporary advances in statistical analysis of extreme events, and the second on using the NIMBLE and climextRemes software for data analysis. The following two days will feature research talks on statistical methodology and applications related to extremes, as well as talks on the science and impacts of extreme events in the Earth system. These talks will include several by researchers in both statistics and fields related to Earth science. Finally, there will be a poster session on the evening of Tuesday, July 23. For more information, see https://cascade.lbl.gov/upcoming-workshops-conferences/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop served two complementary purposes. The first was to provide a venue for statisticians and Earth scientists to share ideas and facilitate collaboration aimed at understanding rare, high-impact events in the Earth system. The second was to introduce graduate students, as well as others wishing to enter into the area of extreme value analysis, to the techniques and challenges that are unique to studying rare events.

The first day of the workshop feature a pair of short courses. The first was on recent advances in the statistics of extremes, taught by Raphael Huser of King Abdullah University of Science and Technology. The second was a hands-on tutorial on software for extreme event analysis, taught by Chris Paciorek of UC Berkeley. The following two days featured research talks on statistical methodology and applications related to extremes. These talks included several by researchers who are not statisticians by training but are deeply involved in studying extremes in the Earth system and their impacts. Finally, there was a poster session on the evening of Tuesday, July 23. Research talks were recorded and posted on the web for subsequent viewing.

The workshop included 57 registered participants, eight of whom attended from countries outside the US. Of the 57 participants, 21 were female, and 35 were graduate students or postdocs. About 80% of the participants were from within academia, with 12 of them having primary affiliations in industry or national labs. 15 presented posters at the poster session. A total of 15 junior researchers were able to participate thanks to funding from this award.
